metadata.case_name: R. B. Bansilal Abirchand Mills (firm and company) v. Labour Court and Workmen

facts.text: Textile mill in Hinganghat known as R. B. Bansilal Abirchand Mills employed about 1000 men, owned by the firm (appellant in second appeal).
Fire broke out in the mill on March 27, 1959 causing appreciable damage to some machines.

Notice under Standing Order No. 19 on March 28, 1959: fire caused heavy loss and extensive damage rendering mills working impracticable until repairs; folding and workshop departments to continue as usual.
Second notice on April 2, 1959: over 60% machines in carding, fly frame and ring frame departments damaged, requiring complete replacement; stoppage of all productive departments.
Letter from Hukumchand Insurance Co. Ltd. dated August 28, 1959: loss to buildings, machinery at Rs. 22,624; later re-assessed to Rs. 37,420 on April 27, 1960.
Third notice on April 29, 1960: no indication of completion date for repairs.
Notice on September 13, 1960: unproductive departments expected to commence on or about September 30, 1960.
Mill transferred to limited company (appellant in first appeal) incorporated on December 8, 1959, for Rs. 34,75,000 (immovables Rs. 11,50,000, movables Rs. 23,25,000).
Towards end of 1961 and beginning of 1962, respondents 2 to 346 in CA No. 2295/1966 filed applications under s.33C(2) claiming lay-off from March 28, 1959 to September 30, 1960.
Appellants in second appeal filed written statement contesting jurisdiction under s.33C(2), stating rights under C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.
Labour Court on November 30, 1962 rejected preliminary objection on jurisdiction.
Appellants filed writ petition under Art.226 before Bombay High Court; rejected on August 25, 1962 holding claim maintainable and Labour Court competent even if lay-off disputed.

Labour Court on November 30, 1962 dismissed 125 applications as res judicata (previously dismissed by Bombay Labour Court for lack of jurisdiction, period March 28, 1959 to May 2, 1960); allowed claims May 3 to September 30, 1960.
Respondents 2 to 493 in CA 2136/1966 filed s.33C applications for period March 28, 1959 to September 30, 1960.
Labour Court on February 29, 1964 held lay-off under s.2(kkk), entitled to 18 months compensation except badli workers.
Writ petitions before Bombay High Court disposed by common judgment February 2, 1965: held running industry no closure; remand for evidence on s.25E(ii) presentation for work; badli not entitled.
High Court granted certificates under Art.133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the Labour Court had jurisdiction to entertain applications for lay-off compensation under s.33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.
Whether there had been a lay-off within the meaning of s.2(kkk) or closure.
Whether compensation under s.25C read with s.25E payable, and if workers presented themselves for work.
Whether badli workers entitled to lay-off compensation.
Quantum of compensation: first proviso to s.25C or full period under s.25C(ii).

petitioner_arguments.text: Labour Court had no jurisdiction under s.33C(2); dispute regarding closure falls under s.10(1)(d) for Industrial Tribunal; lay-off definition requires inability for specific workmen, not wholesale due to calamity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Industrial Disputes Act ss.2(kkk), 7, 10, Second and Third Schedules; closure under Third Schedule item 10

petitioner_arguments.text: Claims under Chapter VA only if no question of closure; large number of workmen makes it collective dispute not individual.
Liability for company starts only after October 1, 1960.
Compensation governed by Standing Orders 19 and 21, no compensation for fire/breakdown.

respondent_arguments.text: 1962 High Court decision on jurisdiction operates as res judicata; appellants failed to seek certificate/SLP.
Lay-off occurred, no closure; industry running as some departments continued.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court has jurisdiction under s.33C(2) for individual claims to compute statutory benefits like lay-off compensation under s.25C, even if right disputed or many claimants; not ousted by plea of closure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.33C(2) covers enforcement of existing rights, incidental enquiry into right/lay-off permitted; lay-off not in Schedules, falls under Second Schedule item 6 for Labour Court.

court_reasoning.text: Not closure but lay-off; notices indicate partial stoppage, some departments continued, business transferred and continued.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Every indication shows running industry, no closure.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court to determine if lay-off or closure; if lay-off, proceed to compensation subject to s.25E proof of presentation for work.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court correctly remanded for evidence on s.25E(ii).

court_reasoning.text: Badli workers not entitled; Standing Orders overridden by Chapter VA s.25J.

holdings.text: Labour Court has jurisdiction under s.33C(2) to entertain and decide lay-off compensation claims, including determining if lay-off occurred or closure.
High Court correctly held no closure but lay-off; remanded properly for s.25E evidence.
Chapter VA s.25J overrides inconsistent Standing Orders.

precedents_cited.case_name: Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P. S. Rajagopalan
precedents_cited.relevance: s.33C(2) for individual rights enforcement, even if disputed; speedy remedy without s.10 reference.
s.33C(2) not confined to awards/settlements/Chapter VA; covers statutory benefits like bonus.

precedents_cited.case_name: U.P. Electric Supply Co. v. R. K. Shukla
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on retrenchment/closure not binding as facts differ; Labour Court can decide factum.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramakrishna Ramanath v. Presiding Officer, Nagpur
precedents_cited.relevance: No dispute on factum of closure raised below; does not help appellants.
Lay-off compensation under Chapter VA claimable via s.33C(1)/(2); State Act no bar.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kays Construction Co. (P) Ltd. v. State of U.P.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction of Labour Court for lay-off compensation claims; definition and conditions for lay-off; overrides Standing Orders.

statutes_cited.name: C.P. and Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: No provision for lay-off compensation; Central Act applies.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Standing Orders 19, 21 inconsistent with Chapter VA, overridden by s.25J.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petitions and certificates for appeal.

outcome.summary: Appeals against High Court order remanding to Labour Court for evidence on s.25E(ii) dismissed; Labour Court jurisdiction upheld; no closure but lay-off; badli workers excluded; Standing Orders overridden.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court remand order upheld; proceedings to continue before Labour Court.

key_quotes.text: The legislative history... clearly indicates that... individual workmen should be given a speedy remedy to enforce their existing individual rights, and so inserted s.33-A... and added s.33-C...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of s.33C(2) for individual statutory claims even if disputed.

key_quotes.text: The claim under s.33-C(2) clearly postulates that the determination... may... be preceded by an enquiry into the existence of the right...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Labour Court can enquire into existence of right like lay-off.

key_quotes.text: In fact the business of this Company was continuing. They in fact continued to employ several employees. their notices say that some portions of the mills would continue to work...
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: Determines no closure, partial operation continued.
